thread.title: Cards on business trip in West Virginia
thread.title_full: Cards on business trip in West Virginia

title: Cards on business trip in West Virginia
text:
Arizona Cardinals arrive in West Virginia on business trip <!--iframe--> Kent Somers , azcentral sports 9:41 p.m. MST October 12, 2015 A view of The Greenbrier in White Sulphur Springs, W.Va. (Photo: Michael Shroyer-USA TODAY Sports) 1 CONNECT 4 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS , W.Va. – Most people arriving at the luxury resort The Greenbrier do so with smiles and great anticipation. 
But this is a business trip for the Cardinals, who are practicing here this week between games at Detroit and Pittsburgh. 
They accomplished the first order of business Sunday, beating the Lions 42-17 , but the victory came with a price. 
Outside linebacker Alex Okafor is expected to miss significant time with a calf injury. 
The Cardinals are hopeful Okafor will miss no more than a month, according to an NFL source. 
Backup linebacker Kenny Demens , a core special teams player suffered a torn ACL and is out for the season. Safety Chris Clemons , also an integral special teamer, suffered a hamstring injury. 
On special teams, “it’s going to be really hard to replace those two guys,” coach Bruce Arians said. 
The team is awaiting MRI results for Okafor and Clemons. 
Arians wasn’t grim when he met with reporters on Monday afternoon, but he seemed subdued. Perhaps it was the trip from Phoenix to Detroit to here. And the injuries likely had something to do with it, too. 
RELATED: NFL standings | NFL scoreboard | NFL stats 
The Cardinals don’t practice until Wednesday, but Arians raved about the facilities at the Greenbrier, where the Saints have held training camp the past two summers. 
“It was a lot easier traveling last night than going all the way back to Phoenix,” Arians said. “We knew coming in here that it was going to be an outstanding facility, that we could get our work done and it wouldn’t be any kind of distraction.” 
Arians said he hadn’t been in this area of West Virginia since he drove here 35 years ago. 
“We actually were going to go snow skiing for the first time ever and it rained,” he said. “We drove back to Blacksburg (Virginia).” 
It was Arians’ first year as a graduate assistant at Virginia Tech. Despite the rain, his group had a good time on the trip. 
“Oh, yes, I promise you,” he said. 
Game balls 
Arians awarded game balls to receiver Larry Fitzgerald , running back Chris Johnson and safeties Rashad Johnson , Deone Bucannon and Tony Jefferson . “I thought they played outstanding, especially Tony,” Arians said. “He was really striking people well. He had a really good game stopping the run and he has been doing it for a while.” 
Jefferson and Bucannon each finished with 11 tackles. Jefferson also forced two fumbles.
